title: Royal Netherlands Air Force – NATO role classification
intro: In NATO recognition, classify by role first (what it is used for).
Use simple English: 'This is a … It is used for …'.

bullets: Used for air combat and precision strike missions.
Often armed and built for high performance.
Fighter Aircraft.why_not: Not a transport aircraft because it is not designed to carry cargo or many passengers.

bullets: Used to move people and cargo over distance.
Large internal space for cargo or passengers.
Often used for logistics and humanitarian support.
Transport Aircraft.why_not: Not a fighter aircraft because it is not built for air-to-air combat.

bullets: Can take off and land vertically.
Can hover and fly at low speed.
Used for transport, attack, and rescue.
Helicopter.why_not: Not a fixed-wing aircraft because it uses rotors, not wings, for lift.

bullets: Usually lighter and simpler than combat aircraft.
Trainer Aircraft.why_not: Not a fighter aircraft because its main role is training, not combat.

bullets: No pilot onboard (remotely piloted or autonomous).
Often used for surveillance and reconnaissance.
Can stay airborne for long periods.
Uncrewed Aerial System (UAS).why_not: Not a helicopter because it is uncrewed and operates differently.

bullets: Special-purpose aircraft or items that do not fit the main roles.
Classify by best match; if unsure, use Other.
Teacher can discuss the closest NATO role.
Other.why_not: Used when the primary role is unclear or unique.
